content.raw:
When a mesh has texture defined in the mesh file the colladaLoader fails to load it, since the colladaLoader is trying to load the image through that the URI in the mesh. We can add a small hack where we pass all the images that we loaded to the colladaloader and modify it so it doesn’t call the threejs texture loader and uses the images as we provide them instead [in case we are loading files not using URLs of course] .

In case this work around does sound nice, I would suggest we make it in a separate PR because PR 117 is getting a little too big and might get harder to review.

There is also the idea that we delay this work around until we replace the ColladaLoader with the new one [ 3 day ago threejs replaced the colladaLoader with the new one on the dev branch].

We can also require the users to provide the URLs of the assets to the sdfviewer and not load the files.

What do you guys think?
content.html:
When a mesh has texture defined in the mesh file the colladaLoader fails to load it, since the colladaLoader is trying to load the image through that the URI in the mesh. We can add a small hack where we pass all the images that we loaded to the colladaloader and modify it so it doesn’t call the threejs texture loader and uses the images as we provide them instead [in case we are loading files not using URLs of course] .

In case this work around does sound nice, I would suggest we make it in a separate PR because PR 117 is getting a little too big and might get harder to review.

There is also the idea that we delay this work around until we replace the ColladaLoader with the new one [ 3 day ago threejs replaced the colladaLoader with the new one on the dev branch].

We can also require the users to provide the URLs of the assets to the sdfviewer and not load the files.

What do you guys think?

content.raw: I feel like we don't need to resuse the logic from SpawnModel. We simply need to add the model at scene origin. The code in this class can be simplified down more. For example, once, you created the obj with the mesh from sdf, just add it to the scene by calling `scene.add`
content.html: I feel like we don't need to resuse the logic from SpawnModel. We simply need to add the model at scene origin. The code in this class can be simplified down more. For example, once, you created the obj with the mesh from sdf, just add it to the scene by calling scene.add

content.html: we don't need to do ray intersection as we're not inserting the model with a mouse

content.raw:
I think it's a good first step to isolate the functionality from `gzsdfparser.js` which is needed into a separate file like you did, it helps us see what is common between the two use cases and what needs to be changed.

In the long run, we should avoid code duplication and improve the `GZ3D.SdfParser` API so that the same file can be used on both cases.
content.html:
I think it's a good first step to isolate the functionality from gzsdfparser.js which is needed into a separate file like you did, it helps us see what is common between the two use cases and what needs to be changed.

In the long run, we should avoid code duplication and improve the GZ3D.SdfParser API so that the same file can be used on both cases.

content.html: I suspect roslibjs is not needed here, it would be interesting to go through this list and see what's actually used

content.raw: The `assets` folder is taken as a relative path from the html file, right? We should make sure the API can work with files that are not located in the same place as the html file. For example, the client opens a file browse window and chooses a file / folder to be loaded from their computer.
content.html: The assets folder is taken as a relative path from the html file, right? We should make sure the API can work with files that are not located in the same place as the html file. For example, the client opens a file browse window and chooses a file / folder to be loaded from their computer.
